item.title: Understanding the Linux Kernel Development Process
item.description:
Understanding the Linux Kernel Development Process
#

The Linux kernel is one of the most influential and widely used open source projects in the world. It powers everything from smartphones and embedded devices to servers, supercomputers, and cloud infrastructure. For developers interested in contributing or simply understanding how the kernel evolves, it is important to know how the development process works. The Linux Foundation’s Beginner’s Guide to Linux Kernel Development (LFD103) outlines the essential concepts involved in maintaining, updating, and releasing the kernel. This article presents a clear overview of the core components of that process.

item.title: Detecting and Fixing Memory Leaks with Valgrind
item.description:
Introduction
#

A memory leak occurs when a program allocates memory dynamically (e.g., using malloc) and fails to release it using free. This leftover allocation can lead to wasted memory resources, eventually causing slowdowns or system crashes in long-running programs.

item.title: QEMU-KVM on Arch Linux: Running Tiny Core Linux in a Lightweight VM
item.description:
QEMU-KVM on Arch Linux: Running Tiny Core Linux in a Lightweight VM
#

Virtualization is a powerful tool for developers, sysadmins, and tinkerers alike. On Linux, QEMU-KVM stands out as a robust, high-performance virtualization stack. In this blog, well walk through setting up QEMU-KVM on Arch Linux and using it to run Tiny Core Linuxa super-lightweight distro perfect for testing and experimentation.
